metadata.name: Texture pattern II #120
metadata.description:
Texture #pattern II is a counter-intuitive visual experiment, it is about creating difference through repetition. One parameter changes in the repetition of fixed sequence in a grid within a grid, this bit of interference creates new patterns by repetition with different visual results.

The piece allows simple interaction, you can click/touch and the colours change within the logic of the algorithm, while maintaining the uniqueness of each token, almost endless variations within each piece are posible. 

You can also add or subtract additional lines or noise to alter its texture.

 's' saves a png 
'j' saves a jpg 
'1','2','4' sets the pixel density to 1,2,4 
'l' allows you to toggle the texture made by lines 
'+' adds more lines
'-' removes lines
'n' allows you to toggle extra noise 'm' adds more noise 'b' removes some noise

metadata.name: Context-Free Wind #2
metadata.description:
Context-Free Wind is a poetry generator and visualizer created by Ross Goodwin (https://rossgoodwin.com) in vanilla JavaScript without the use of any framework or external libraries, excluding code required by fxhash. The generator uses a custom context-free grammar algorithm and word lists assembled by the creator to produce (...admittedly, fairly strange...) sentences.

These sentences are then blown aloft by a procedural "wind" -- based on the algorithm Goodwin first explored in the following Dweet:
https://www.dwitter.net/d/23927

metadata.name: Dencity #929
metadata.description:
Dencity is a generative art project inspired by aerial views of cities with a high density of buildings. Its perspective effect, its perfectly imprecise lines, its subtle textures and its very advanced level of detail give it the appearance of a hand-drawn work.

Behind the visible art (the image) hides another form of art, an extremely complex algorithm capable of calculating and drawing in 2D each variation of the Dencity project. To draw a variation, the algorithm notably takes around 3,000,000 to 20,000,000 random decisions based on the hash of the mint and draws around 800,000 to 4,000,000 lines to create all the strokes and texture effects.

Made with ❤️, code and p5js.

metadata.name: Fizz 2.0 #11
metadata.description:
Experimental Art.

This piece is inspired by a mathematical theorem known as 'Circle packing'. This algorithm aims to cram a bunch of circles into space as tightly as possible. This is a well-explored topic throughout the history of mathematics, but at the end of the day it's mathematics, it's BORING. So to make 'Fizz' a little bit thrilling and different, I wrote an algorithm that randomly draws 450 circles with totally different radiuses (range(width * 0.1, width * 0.001) to be exact) on a canvas, and checks each circle, if the randomly chosen location is a good fit for a new circle to avoid collisions.

Combined with some cool colors and gradients for both the background and the circles, this procedure is all it took to produce 'Fizz'.
Bereft of meaning, feel free to interpret it as you please.

metadata.name: A Burroughs Quote #264
metadata.description:
A Burroughs Quote is part of the fxhash interactive minting experience at Proof of People, London 2022

The birth of the Cut Up Method via the third mind. Dream Machine. Fragments. Morocco. It takes one to know one.

Esoteric rarity. Value is intended to be determined by viewer aesthetic alone.

Chrome or Firefox is recommended for your maximum viewing pleasure.

This artwork was created using p5js.

lisaorth.xyz
linktr.ee/lisaorthstudio
twitter: @lisaorthstudio

metadata.name: Polar Grid #923
metadata.description:
Polar Grid is part of the fxhash live minting experience at Proof of People, London 2022.

This is a study of color, motion, and composition, and an homage to cinema as an artform. Colorful shapes overlap and pulse in a ever repeating dance. An abstracted movie experience. Each color palette in the series (except one) is inspired by a different film director (if you want a real challenge, see how many you can guess without looking at the feature names).

The palettes were extracted from movie stills or movie posters and fine tuned by hand. As often, I have to thank independent tool makers for their indirect help. My gratitude goes to David Aerne for FarbVélo and Fabrizio Bianchi for Coolors.

The code for Polar Grid is based on early iterations of what ultimately became my carat series. Both projects come from the same fascination for color as a system, even though I used a different approach here. You could call this a carat prequel.

The animation is done using a technique called polar noise. This makes it so the motion of all elements ends up repeating in the same amount of time. This is useful for generating motion that loops perfectly while still appearing organic. In this particular case, the animation repeats every π × 100 seconds.

A challenge in building any generative system is to find the right balance between coherence and variety. I designed the system with the large edition size in mind. During development I generated hundreds of iterations and tweaked my code to make sure that every iteration is truly unique and fits the overall aesthetic of the collection.

I truly hope you will enjoy your own little abstract movie.

— Raphaël de Courville


Released: July 6th 2022

Medium: p5.js, html canvas, css

Reference: sk220621


**About the artist**

Raphaël de Courville is a generative artist, streamer, and educator. His artistic work is an exploration of generative systems, patterns, interactivity, and time. Born in Paris, he lives and works in Berlin.


**Instructions**

- Click/Tap or press SPACEBAR to play and pause the animation

In Fullscreen mode (desktop only):
- Press UP or DOWN arrows to adjust image quality (Note: this can affect performance)
- Press F to hide/show the browser UI
